China b Technical Centre for Soil, Agriculture and Rural Ecology and Environment, Ministry of Ecology and Environment, Beijing 100012, PR China Technical Centre for Soil, Agriculture and Rural Ecology and Environment, Ministry of Ecology and Environment Beijing 100012 PR China Technical Centre for Soil, Agriculture and Rural Ecology and Environment, Ministry of Ecology and Environment, Beijing 100012, P.R. China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Nowadays, MnO2-based catalysts have been widely applied in environmental fields, especially the removal of HCHO at room temperature. However, the moisture resistance of the catalyst is still a challenge. In this study, a series of MnTix/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts were prepared by the methods of redox precipitation and impregnation, which showed excellent HCHO removal efficiency under humid conditions. When the catalyst accumulatively treated ca. 25 ppm of HCHO, there was still a HCHO conversion of 87.5% and the activity can be restored by washing and drying. DFT calculations, XPS, and TG results showed that Ti-modification could inhibit the adsorption of physisorbed water on the catalyst surface, thereby weakening the competitive adsorption between H2O and HCHO. This study provides a feasible strategy for the removal of HCHO under humid conditions. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Titanium modification MnO2 Formaldehyde decomposition Relative humidity 1 Introduction Formaldehyde (HCHO) is one of the notorious indoor air pollutants and mainly derived from substandard building materials, wooden furniture, and various types of decorative materials [1]. The release cycle of HCHO is as long as 3 ~ 15 years, and people spend most of their time indoors, which causes long-term harm to human health [2,3]. As early as 2004, HCHO has been identified as a carcinogen by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) [4–6]. Even long-term exposure to low-concentration HCHO can lead to dermatitis, throat inflammation, pulmonary edema, and other diseases [7–9]. Therefore, the development of methods for removing HCHO efficiently is of great significance. In recent years, various methods have been studied to remove HCHO [8,10,11], among which catalytic oxidation has become the most promising strategy due to its low energy consumption, little secondary pollution, and high efficiency [12,13]. Noble metal catalysts can completely convert HCHO into CO2 and H2O at room temperature [14–18], however, the scarcity and high cost of noble metals limit their commercial application. To cope with this problem, non-noble metal catalysts have gradually attracted concerns from researchers. Sekine et al. [19] firstly compared the HCHO removal efficiency of different metal oxides, including Ag2O, PdO, CoO, MnO2, TiO2, CeO2, Mn3O4, La2O3, ZnO, V2O5, and found that MnO2 showed the best activity at 25 ℃, the 24-hour HCHO conversion was 91%. Since then, Zhang et al. [20] reported that different crystalline forms of MnO2 (α, β, γ, δ-MnO2) all showed effects in catalytic oxidation of HCHO, among which the δ-MnO2 performed best. Humidity is one of the most important factors affecting the catalytic activity of removing HCHO [6,21–24]. Formate is the main intermediate product in the oxidation reaction system of HCHO, and its further conversion into CO2 and H2O is the rate-determining step in the whole process [6]. And H2O has a positive effect on the formation and consumption of formate intermediates [25]. Wang et al. [8] reported that the activity of layered MnO2 under relative humidity (RH) of 33% and 65% was better than that under RH of 0%. However, when the RH reached 92%, the HCHO conversion decreased significantly. Ma et al. [23] found that only associatively adsorbed water can promote the complete decomposition of HCHO, and the competitive adsorption between surface adsorbed water and HCHO is one of the main reasons for the deactivation of the catalysts. The activity in humid conditions is an important index to evaluate the catalyst. Therefore, numerous methods have been tried to improve the moisture resistance of the catalysts. Some research teams have improved the moisture resistance by introducing hydrophobic substances. Zhao et al. [26] prepared a series of AgCu/HZ catalysts by using hydrophobic zeolite as a carrier, the HCHO breakthrough capacity remained stable under RH of 20~93%. Shi et al. [27] found that 3D ordered mesoporous structure and high specific surface area are benefical to improving the catalytic performance, the complete conversion temperature of HCHO was ~ 70 ℃. And the catalyst prepared by the KIT-6-templating strategy had more hydrophobic species on the surface, thus showing better moisture resistance. In addition, the moisture resistance could be also improved by the method of element doping. Liu et al. [24] synthesized hierarchical porous MnO2 through the method of freezing induction, the existence of K+ and large mesopores could weaken the capillary condensation in MnO2 under humid conditions, thereby improving the moisture resistance of the catalysts. He et al. [28] prepared a Cu/Mn composite oxide catalyst using palygorskite as a carrier and used it for HCHO removal. The CO2 yield was over 90% at ca. 200 ℃, and the introduction of Cu improved the reducibility and moisture resistance of the composite. TiO2 is usually used as the carrier for noble metal catalysts [29–31]. However, few experiments have been carried out to explore the significant impact of simple Ti-modification on improving the moisture resistance of HCHO removal catalysts. γ-Al2O3 is widely used as the carrier due to its porous and high specific surface area. The structured γ-Al2O3/Al carrier prepared by anodizing technology can effectively solve the problems of poor mass transfer and large pressure drop, and, more importantly, the characteristic of flexibility makes it easier to couple with the purifier. Herein, we synthesized a series of flexible mesh-type MnTix/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts using the methods of redox precipitation and impregnation. Firstly, the activities of the catalysts under different RH were measured in the 3 m3 air cabin. The effects of Ti-modification on the structure of MnO2 particles and the activities of the catalysts were further analyzed. Secondly, the mechanism of Ti-modification reducing the competitive adsorption of H2O and HCHO was investigated by experimental method and verified by DFT calculations. Ultimately, a 104-hour aging experiment with a total HCHO treatment capacity of ca. 25 ppm was conducted. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation All chemicals used for catalyst preparation were analytical grade and used without further purification. In this study, the flexible mesh-type carrier was prepared by anodizing method [32]. Firstly, an aluminum mesh (1060-type, ≥ 99.6%, 280 × 280 mm2) was soaked in a 10 wt% sodium hydroxide solution for 4 min and then soaked in a 10 wt% nitric acid solution for 2 min, followed by being rinsed with deionized water. The cleaned aluminum mesh was anodized in a 104 L 0.4 mol/L oxalic acid solution with a current density of 25 A/m2 at 20 °C for 10 h. Secondly, the obtained mesh (anodic aluminum oxide, AAO) was rinsed with deionized water and dried at room temperature, the residual oxalic acid was removed by calcination at 350 °C for 1 h. Subsequently, the AAO was immersed in deionized water at 80 °C for 1 h, and then dried at room temperature to obtain anodic boehmite (denoted as γ-AlOOH). Finally, the γ-AlOOH was calcined at 500 ℃ for 4 h to obtain the γ-Al2O3/Al carrier. The catalyst was synthesized through a two-step method. Firstly, the Ti-modified carrier was prepared by the impregnation method. Four pieces of γ-Al2O3/Al carriers (140 × 220 mm2) were immersed in a 1.6 L of potassium titanyl oxalate (K2TiO (C2O4)2.2 H2O) solution at 85 ℃ for 4 h, and then naturally dried and calcined at 500 ℃ for 4 h. Different contents of Ti could be achieved by controlling the concentrations of the solution (0.15, 0.23, 0.35, 0.50 mol/L). The corresponding carriers were denoted as Tix/γ-Al2O3/Al (x = 0, 1.1, 1.9, 2.5), where x was the loading of Ti. Secondly, MnO2 was loaded onto the Tix/γ-Al2O3/Al carrier by the method of redox precipitation [33]. In a typical synthesis, 20.5 g of KMnO4 and 18.5 g of (NH4)2C2O4 were dissolved in a square quartz cylinder with 2.6 L of deionized water, and four pieces of Tix/γ-Al2O3/Al carriers (140 × 220 cm2) were immersed in it. The mixed solution was heated to 90 ℃ under vigorous stirring, and the weight percentage of Mn was set as ca. 10 wt%. After the reaction, the meshes were rinsed and dried at 105 ℃ for 6 h to obtain MnTix/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts. All the calcination processes were carried out in a muffle furnace with a heating rate of 5 ℃/min. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area (S BET) was determined on Micromeritics ASAP 2020-M nitrogen adsorption apparatus. The pore volume and corresponding pore size distribution were calculated by using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Samples were degassed at 350 °C for 12 h. The contents of Mn and Ti were measured by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) on Agilent 710ES. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of all samples was performed on Rigaku Ultima IV using a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 0.15418 nm), operated at 40 kV and 100 mA. The scanning rate was 2°/min, and the 2θ was between 10° and 80°. The Raman spectra were recorded on a Laser Micro-Raman Spectrometer (Renishaw, Britain) using a 532 nm laser as the excitation source. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) observations were carried out on FEI NanoSEM 450 operated at 15 kV. The surface elements and chemical states were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on Thermo Scientific K-Alpha using Al Kα (λ = 1486.6 eV) as excitation X-ray source. The C 1s peak from adventitious carbon was set as 284.8 eV to calibrate the binding energies of all elements. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was performed on Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS20 from 400 cm–1 to 4000 cm–1. H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was recorded on Micromeritics ChemSorb 2720. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was performed by WRT-3 P-TGA, the temperature range is from 25 ℃ to 600 ℃ with a heating rate of 10 ℃/min. 2.3 Catalytic activity evaluation To simulate the indoor environment, a 3 m3 air cabin (GB/T 18801–2015) was designed. As shown in Fig. 1, the air cabin was made of tempered glass and equipped with four gas sampling ports, a stirring fan, and an internal circulator. The catalytic activity evaluation at room temperature of the catalyst under different RH conditions was carried out in it. The RH in the air cabin was measured by the hygrometer, and jointly adjusted by a humidifier and a dehumidifier. Before the experiment, the gas in the air cabin was completely displaced with fresh air to ensure that there was no residual HCHO contamination. Four pieces of flexible mesh-type catalysts (130 × 175 mm2, rhombus mesh size: 1 × 2 mm2) with a thickness of 0.4 mm were fixed in the air purifier (KR-100, Shanghai Huaming Hi-Tech (Group) Co., Ltd.) and placed in the center of the cabin floor. The catalysts were used without pre-heated. The closed furnace with watch glass was preheated in advance, then a certain volume of HCHO solution (37.0 wt%) was injected onto it. The internal circulator was kept running to promote the diffusion of HCHO. After 20 min, the gas in the air cabin was mixed completely, and the concentration of HCHO was stable at ca. 0.9 ppm. Next, the purifier was turned on, and the catalysts started to contact HCHO gas and react at room temperature under its drive. An air sampler (JH-6) was used to collect gas for 5 min at a flow rate of 0.5 L/min, and the interval between each collection was 3 min. Finally, the HCHO concentration was measured and calculated by the phenol reagent-spectrophotometry method (723 N visible spectrophotometer, λ = 630 nm, GB/T 18204.26–2000). The volume of collected gas under standard temperature and pressure (STP) could be converted based on the following equation: (1) V 0 = V t × T 0 273 + t × P P 0 Where V 0 (L) is the volume of collected gas (STP), V t (L) is the volume of collected gas (sampling flow rate × absorbed liquid volume), T 0 (K) is the Kelvin thermodynamic temperature (STP), t (℃) is the temperature at the gas collection point, P 0 (kPa) is the pressure at the gas collection point (STP), P (kPa) is the pressure at the gas collection point. The HCHO concentration was determined by the following equation: (2) c = ( A – A 0 ) × B g V 0 Where c (mg/m3) is the HCHO concentration, A is the absorbance (Abs) of sample solution, A 0 is the Abs of blank sample, B g (0.311 μg/Abs) is the calculation factor calculated by standard curve. The HCHO conversion was calculated by the following equation: (3) HCHO conversion % = c 0 – c t c 0 × 100 % Where c 0 represents the initial HCHO concentration (ppm) and c t is the concentration at t min. 2.4 DFT method To investigate the influence of Ti-modification on adsorption energies, the Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations were performed on the Vienna ab-initio simulation package (VASP) [34,35] equipped with Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [36]. The cutoff energy was set as 450 eV. For all the models, the surface Brillouin zone was sampled with a 2 × 2 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-points grid mesh. To avoid interactions between duplicate models along the z-direction, the vacuum spacing between any two adjacent slabs in the z-direction was set as 15 Å. The two layers in the bottom of the models were anchored while the other layers were relaxed. The adsorption energies ( E ads ) of the models were defined as follows: (4) E ads = E total – E ad – E sub Where the E total , E ad , E sub are the total surface energy containing the adsorbate, the energy of isolated molecules and the energy of the substrate, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The HCHO removal behavior of Mn/γ-Al2O3/Al in the 3 m3 air cabin under different RH conditions H2O molecules plays a key role in the catalytic oxidation reaction system of HCHO [23]. In this work, the removal efficiency of HCHO over Mn/γ-Al2O3/Al catalyst under different RH conditions was studied firstly. The activities of the flexible mesh-type catalysts were evaluated in the 3 m3 air cabin. The RH was set as 20%, 40%, and 80%, respectively. The initial concentration of HCHO was ca. 0.9 ppm, the temperature was controlled at 25 ± 2 ℃, and the cross section velocity of the air purifier outlet was adjusted to 1.8 m/s. Fig. 2a shows the reaction behaviors of Mn/γ-Al2O3/Al catalyst in the 3 m3 air cabin. The activity was not significantly affected when the RH was below 40%, and the HCHO conversion reached 87% after 80 min. However, when the RH was increased to 80%, the activity of the Mn/γ-Al2O3/Al catalyst decreased significantly, indicating that high RH could inhibit the activity of the catalyst. Fig. 2b exhibits the possible mechanism with the participation of H2O in the oxidation reaction system of HCHO. Firstly, H2O molecules can be associatively adsorbed on oxygen vacancies, providing active sites for the adsorption of HCHO [23]; meanwhile, H2O molecules can react with surface active oxygen species (O–, O2–) to form surface hydroxyl groups and ensure the oxidation of HCHO [37]. However, under humid conditions, H2O molecules are easily combined with the hydroxyl groups on the surface of the catalysts [21,38]. The competitive adsorption between H2O and HCHO inhibits the adsorption of HCHO molecules on the surface of the catalysts, resulting in the decrease of HCHO removal efficiency. In addition, H2O molecules condenses under humid conditions, possibly leading to pore-filling and reducing the effective contact area between the catalysts and the gas [39]. In summary, the experimental result proves that H2O molecules could inhibit the activity of the catalyst under humid conditions. Therefore, a kind of catalyst designed with low H2O adsorption capacity is a strategy to deal with the humid reaction system. 3.2 The effects of Ti-loading on enhancing the HCHO removal efficiency In this work, DFT calculations were utilized to investigate the effect of Ti-modification on the adsorption of H2O on the surface of the catalysts, as shown in Fig. 3. The (0 0 6) plan was chosen as the main exposed crystal plane, and this will be discussed in the XRD section. Two models (δ-MnO2 and MnTi) were established, the MnTi model was simulated by replacing Mn atoms with Ti atoms. The adsorption energy of MnTi for H2O was − 0.63 eV, which was 0.23 eV higher than that of δ-MnO2, indicating the adsorption of H2O was inhibited after Ti-modification. Therefore, a series of MnTix/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts with different contents of Ti were developed, as summarized in Table 1. Fig. 4 demonstrates the microstructure and morphology of carrier and MnO2 particles. As shown in Fig. 4a, the γ-Al2O3/Al carrier possessed a porous structure. Fig. 4b and c show that the TiO2 particles were evenly distributed on the surface of the carriers. Moreover, with the increase of Ti loading, the size of TiO2 particles gradually became larger and agglomerated, and finally blocked the pores, as shown in Fig. 4d. Fig. 4e shows that spherical structure MnO2 particles could be observed on the surface of Mn/γ-Al2O3/Al after loading MnO2, as reported in the literature [40]. With the increase of Ti loading, the MnO2 particles gradually became smaller and the fluffy MnO2 clusters with filamentous structure could be observed when the Ti-loading was 1.9 wt%, as shown in Fig. 4g. TiO2 was able to promote the formation of tiny crystal nuclei during the crystallization of MnO2, which was conducive to the good dispersion of MnO2. However, excessive loading of Ti led to the agglomeration of MnO2, as shown in Fig. 4h. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and the corresponding pore size distribution curves of the carrier and different catalysts are displayed in Fig. 5. Fig. 5a shows that all the catalysts conformed to the typical Type Ⅳ isotherm. More specifically, the γ-Al2O3/Al carrier, Mn/γ-Al2O3/Al, and MnTi1.1/γ-Al2O3/Al showed typical H2-type hysteresis loops, which were associated with ink-bottle pores [41]. The MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al and MnTi2.5/γ-Al2O3/Al exhibited both H2 (p/p 0 = 0.4 ~ 0.9) and H3-type (p/p 0 = 0.9 ~ 1.0) hysteresis loops, indicating the coexistence of ink-bottle and slit-shaped mesopores [42]. As shown in Fig. 5b, all samples showed the same most probable pore size (3.6 ~ 4 nm), further confirming the presence of mesoporous in the catalysts. As summarized in Table 1, Mn/γ-Al2O3/Al showed a specific surface of 193.8 m2/g, which was much higher than that of γ-Al2O3/Al carrier (95.7 m2/g). After Ti-modification, the surface area of the MnTix/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts was in the following order: MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al (252.8 m2/g) > MnTi1.1/γ-Al2O3/Al (203.1 m2/g) > MnTi2.5/γ-Al2O3/Al (200.5 m2/g), and it has been reported that the catalyst with a higher surface area exhibits higher HCHO capture capacity [43]. The reason for the decrease of the specific surface area caused by excessive Ti-loading was that the pores were blocked by the TiO2, which is consistent with the results of SEM. Fig. 6a shows the XRD patterns of various samples. After Ti-modification, the diffraction peaks at 25.3°, 36.9°, and 48.0° could be indexed to a typical crystalline phase of anatase-type TiO2 (JCPDS #21–1272) [44]. All MnO2-based catalysts showed broad peaks, which was due to the poor crystallinity. The diffraction peaks at 12.3°, 18.7°, and 36.8° of samples (Ⅲ) ~ (Ⅵ) could be respectively indexed to the (0 0 2), (1 0 1), and (0 0 6) planes of birnessite-type MnO2 (i.e. δ-MnO2) (JCPDS #18–0802) [6]. And the peaks at 37.6° showed high intensity in comparison with other planes, suggesting that the (0 0 6) plane exposed large quantities. The peak at 28.7° could be indexed to cryptomelane-type MnO2 (i.e. OMS-2) (JCPDS #29–1020) [45], the reason might be that in the preparation process, the layered structure collapsed and transformed into pore structure under high temperature for a long time [46]. Notably, the diffraction peaks at 32.9°, corresponding to the (2 2 2) plane of bixbyite Mn2O3 (JCPDS #41–1442) [47], was found in Mn/γ-Al2O3/Al and MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al. The above results suggest the existence of mixed crystal phase MnOx. Raman spectroscopy was used to identify the crystal structure of manganese oxide species due to its high sensitivity. Fig. 6b shows the Raman spectra of Mn/γ-Al2O3/Al and MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al. The characteristic peaks in the low-frequency (500 ~ 510 cm–1 and 575 ~ 585 cm–1) belonging to δ-MnO2 could not be observed from the two samples, while the strong peak at ca. 640 cm–1 could be indexed to the A1 g symmetric stretching vibration mode of Mn-O lattice, indicating the existence of [MnO6] octahedron [48]. And the peak intensities of the two samples were strong and almost the same, indicating the existence of a large amount of cations (K+), and few Ti ions enter the interlayer or channel to lead to the lattice distortion [12]. The weak peak at ca. 348 cm–1 corresponded to the asymmetric stretching of bridging oxygen species (Mn-O-Mn) of Mn2O3 [49,50], which is consistent with the XRD results. Moreover, the band at ca. 287 cm–1 could be attributed to the deformation modes of Mn-O-Mn [51]. Furthermore, H2-TPR analysis was used to investigate the effect of Mn-Ti interaction on reducibility. As shown in Fig. 7, two reduction peaks appearing at 200 ~ 450 ℃ corresponded to the reduction process: KxMnO2 → Mn2O3 → Mn3O4 → MnO [52]. The α-reduction peak of Mn/γ-Al2O3/Al centered at 326.4 ℃, and with the increase of Ti-loading, the α-reduction peak shifted to a lower temperature and reached the lowest (309.5 ℃) at the Ti-loading of 1.9 wt%, indicating that the presence of TiO2 improves the reducibility of surface oxygen [53]. 3.3 The HCHO removal kinetics behavior and mechanism of MnTix/γ-Al2O3/Al in the 3 m3 air cabin under humid conditions Fig. 8 displays the comparison variation in the catalytic activities of a series of MnTix/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts under RH of 40%. The result shows that Ti-modification could tremendously promote the activities of the catalysts, especially, MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al possessed the best HCHO removal efficiency. The HCHO conversion at 40 min reached 91%, which was 23% higher than that of the Mn/γ-Al2O3/Al (68%). After 48 min, the conversion of HCHO reached 96%. However, when the loading of Ti was further increased from 1.9 wt% to 2.5 wt%, the HCHO conversion of MnTi2.5/γ-Al2O3/Al at 40 min decreased to 73%, which was possibly due to the partial destruction of the pore structure caused by the high-concentration solution of K2TiO (C2O4)2. The MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al catalyst was selected for further investigation of HCHO removal under different RH conditions. Fig. 9a shows that when the RH was below 40%, the activity of the MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al was not significantly affected by the moisture, either. The HCHO conversion of MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al (93.1%) was much higher than that of Mn/γ-Al2O3/Al (72.1%) when the RH reached 80%. Furthermore, the kinetic analyses of Mn/γ-Al2O3/Al and MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al under RH of 80% were carried out. Different from the traditional fixed-bed reactors with a high concentration of HCHO, the aim of this paper was to study the low-concentration and large-volume (3 m3 cabin) reaction. Herein, the 3 m3 air cabin was assumed to be an integrating reactor. With the process of reaction, diffusion gradually became the speed control step, so the data within 40 min was used for kinetic fitting. The apparent reaction rate constant of the HCHO catalytic oxidation reaction that occurred in the mesh-type catalyst bed was calculated according to the pseudo-first-order kinetics model equation shown in Eq. (5): (5) – r HCHO = dc HCHO dt = K app , HCHO · c A , HCHO Fig. 9b proves that the removal rate of HCHO agreed with the pseudo-first-order kinetics. After loading Ti of 1.9 wt%, the pseudo-first-order rate constant (K app, HCHO) of HCHO degradation increased from 0.01879 to 0.04480 under RH of 80%, suggesting that a high reaction rate could be maintained even under RH of 80%. And this trend is consistent with that of the HCHO conversion. The above results verify that 1.9 wt% of Ti loading could effectively improve the catalytic activity of the catalyst under humid conditions. Based on the results of kinetics investigation that Ti-modification could improve the moisture resistance of the catalyst, we proposed an assumption: the existence of Ti could inhibit the adsorption of H2O on the surface of the catalyst. The FT-IR spectra of different catalysts were conducted to investigate the surface functional groups, as shown in Fig. 10. The strong peak at ca. 3425 cm–1 was attributed to the stretching as well as bending vibrations of the surface adsorbed water or Al-OH [54], and the medium intensity peak at ca. 1638 cm–1 corresponded to the stretching and bending vibrations of OH [55]. The weak peak at 1420 cm–1 could be assigned to the asymmetric stretching vibrations of CO [56]. The peak at ca. 1080 cm–1 was attributed to the bending vibration peak of the Al-OH bond in the crystal lattice [57]. The vibrational peaks at ca. 586 cm–1 and 750 cm–1 were due to the vibrations of AlO6 [58]. Moreover, the peak located at ca. 520 cm–1 can be ascribed to the Mn-O vibrations of the [MnO6] [59]. In summary, the abundant hydroxyl groups were benefical to improving the catalytic activity, however, they were easily combined with H2O under humid conditions, resulting in the competitive adsorption of water and HCHO. Furthermore, XPS was applied to analyze the surface element valence and chemical composition of the catalysts, the survey spectra of different samples and high resolution spectra of Mn 2p, Ti 2p, Mn 3s, and O 1s are shown in Fig. 11. The quantitative analyses are summarized in Table 2. With the help of CasaXPS software, the Mn 2p3/2 peak could be deconvoluted into two peaks (Fig. 11b), which could be assigned to Mn4+ (642.9 ± 0.1 eV) and Mn3+ (641.6 ± 0.1 eV), respectively [60]. The Mn3+ /Mn4+ atomic ratio of MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al (0.67) was much higher than that of the other three catalysts. Higher content of Mn3+ could lead to the Jahn-Teller distortion and then promote the formation of oxygen vacancies to maintain charge conservation (Eq. 6) [61,62]. As shown in Fig. 11d, the binding energy of Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2p3/2 were at 461.0 ~ 467.0 eV and 454.5 ~ 461.0 eV, respectively [63]. The mixed valence states of Ti3+ and Ti4+ promoted the electron transfer between Mn and Ti, the electrons of Ti3+ transferred to Mn4+ to generate more Ti4+ (Table 2), and Mn4+ converted to Mn3+ after accepting electrons. (6) Mn 4 + – O 2 – – Mn 4 + → Mn 3 + – V O – Mn 3 + – 1 2 O 2 ↑ The difference of binding energies (ΔE, Fig. 11c) between Mn 3 s doublet peaks could be used to calculate the average oxidation state (AOS) of Mn by using the following empirical formula: AOS = 8.956 – 1.126 × ΔE [64]. As shown in Fig. 11c, the ΔE values of four catalysts were 4.76 eV, 4.87 eV, 5.08 eV, and 4.96 eV, respectively, and the corresponding AOS values were presented in Table 2 and followed the order: MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al ＜ MnTi2.5/γ-Al2O3/Al ＜ MnTi1.1/γ-Al2O3/Al ＜ Mn/γ-Al2O3/Al, indicating the coexistence of Mn3+ and Mn4+, as observed in the results of deconvoluted Mn 2p3/2 peaks. As shown in Fig. 11e, the deconvolution of the O 1 s spectra reveals that the peaks located near 529.6 ~ 530.1 eV, 531.2 ~ 531.6 eV, and ~ 533 eV could be assigned to lattice oxygen (Olatt), surface adsorbed oxygen (Osurf), and surface adsorbed water (Owat), respectively [65]. As summarized in Table 2, the MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al catalyst owned the highest content of surface adsorbed oxygen (75.35%), such as O2–, O–, and hydroxyl groups, which could promote the oxidation of HCHO at room temperature [66]. The content of Owat in MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al was lower compared with other catalysts, suggesting that H2O molecules were not easy to be adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst. This phenomenon indicates that Ti-modification could weaken the H-O-H bond strength of physically adsorbed water, and further attenuate the competitive adsorption between H2O and HCHO on the surface of the catalyst. If the physically adsorbed water molecules were adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst with weak bond energy, they can be removed by heat treatment at low temperature [67]. Given the above-mentioned facts, the following experiments were designed to further prove that Ti-modification could weaken the H-O-H bond strength of the physically adsorbed water and reduce its amount. Firstly, the activities of the catalysts (Mn/γ-Al2O3/Al and MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al) were evaluated under RH of 40% and 80%, respectively, then the content of physically adsorbed water on the surface was analyzed by TG. Finally, the used catalysts were dried at 105 ℃ for 2 h, and then analyzed again by TG. Fig. 12 shows that the weight loss between 30 ℃ and 150 ℃ was mainly due to the removal of physically adsorbed water and adsorbed interlayer water of birnessite-type MnO2 [8,68]. When the RH was increased from 40% to 80%, the weight loss of Mn/γ-Al2O3/Al and MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al was elevated by 2.8% and 3.1%, respectively, indicating that both catalysts were affected by the competing adsorption of H2O under humid conditions. The samples treated with HCHO in the above humid conditions were exposed to thermal weight loss analysis again after being dried at 105 ℃ for 2 h. As shown in Fig. 12b, the weight loss peak of MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al returned to the level under RH of 40%, while the weight loss peak of Mn/γ-Al2O3/Al did not change significantly after being dried (Fig. 12a). This phenomenon indicates that the physically adsorbed water could be removed by low-temperature heat treatment with the existence of TiO2. In addition, the weight loss peak shifted from 83 ℃ to 94 ℃ after Ti-modification, indicating that the low-temperature heat treatment resistance of birnessite-MnO2 was improved with the help of TiO2. In general, the XPS, DFT and TG results show that the presence of TiO2 could effectively inhibit the adsorption of water on the catalyst surface, which was the main reason for the high activity of MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al under humid conditions. 3.4 Aging evaluation In the final section, the aging evaluation was carried out. Before the aging experiment, a HCHO removal experiment (ca. 0.9 ppm) was carried out over fresh catalyst firstly. The procedure of the aging experiment was as follows: (1) ca. 5 ppm HCHO was injected into the 3 m3 air cabin for the 24-hour aging, during which the air purifier was kept on; (2) after the aging, ca. 0.9 ppm HCHO was injected into the 3 m3 air cabin to conduct the activity evaluation again. The above two steps were repeated 4 times. Fig. 13 reveals that the MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al showed a better anti-aging property than the Mn/γ-Al2O3/Al. After 4 times of aging, the HCHO conversion of MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al was 87.5% at 96 min, which was only 10% lower than that of the fresh catalyst. Finally, the catalyst was regenerated by being washed and dried, and the HCHO conversion returned to 95% at 64 min, indicating that the catalyst deactivation was reversible. Therefore, the MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al catalyst is an extremely prospective alternative in the application for indoor HCHO removal. 4 Conclusions In this work, a series of Ti-modified Mn/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts were successfully prepared and applied in low-concentration HCHO removal under humid conditions. The MnTi1.9/γ-Al2O3/Al catalyst showed the best activity, excellent moisture resistance, and durability in the 3 m3 air cabin. Characterization and calculation results show that Ti-modification changed the physicochemical properties of the catalysts. The main conclusions are concluded as follows: (1) The specific surface area was increased with the existence of TiO2, which could promote the dispersion of MnO2 particles. When the Ti loading was 1.9 wt%, the MnO2 on the surface of the catalyst presented a filamentous structure; (2) Experimental results combined with DFT calculations prove that the main reason for the improvement of the moisture resistance by Ti-modification was due to the weaker H-O-H bond energy; (3) An aging experiment in the 3 m3 air cabin was designed. After the 104-hour aging, the total HCHO treatment capacity reached ca. 25 ppm, and a 87.5% HCHO conversion could still be attained. Besides, such an inactivation could be restored by simply washing with water. coredata.dc:description: Nowadays, MnO2-based catalysts have been widely applied in environmental fields, especially the removal of HCHO at room temperature. However, the moisture resistance of the catalyst is still a challenge. In this study, a series of MnTix/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts were prepared by the methods of redox precipitation and impregnation, which showed excellent HCHO removal efficiency under humid conditions. When the catalyst accumulatively treated ca. 25 ppm of HCHO, there was still a HCHO conversion of 87.5% and the activity can be restored by washing and drying. DFT calculations, XPS, and TG results showed that Ti-modification could inhibit the adsorption of physisorbed water on the catalyst surface, thereby weakening the competitive adsorption between H2O and HCHO. This study provides a feasible strategy for the removal of HCHO under humid conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Ti-modification enhanced the activity of flexible mesh-type Mn/γ-Al2O3/Al catalyst for indoor HCHO removal under humid conditions
